speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Well, welcome to, again, the second annual Future Fossils podcast with Complexity Weekend.

text: I don't know
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So for folks who aren't familiar with Future Fossils,
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: The show has two main themes.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: One is about identifying our place in deep time, and the other is interrogating our models of time and subjectivity and generally playing footloose with constructed categories such as self and other, nature and culture.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: for the sake of facilitating the epistemic shift that seems necessary to navigate this turbulent century.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So that's the tone I'm going to be keeping as the host and moderator for this discussion.

text: elicit the collective intelligence of these participants as best I can.

speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Maybe we can just go out of a hat randomly.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Meredith, Michaela, Tim, and Andrea, in that order, if you care to just tell folks.

text: Is that an invitation to jump in?

text: Yes.

speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Yeah.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Well, my name is Meredith Trumbull and I'm a visual artist and a writer about visual art, which became necessary in order to try to talk about things that
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: at the time that I started weren't being talked about as much in art criticism and writing.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And I've been interested in absurdity, complexity, things that don't quite match up for as long as I can remember.

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It led me into a residency at the Complexity Sciences Center at UC Davis, which has been home to a long running
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: a project of my own.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And I also like to think about the history of art and technology.

speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Hi, everyone.

speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So, and I might need to explain that a little bit more.

speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So is everyone contributing equally?

text: And I'm learning with all of you because my background is law, it's human sciences, humanities, and it's a very rich environment here for me.

text: Thank you.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So something that comes up for me in listening to all of you introduce yourselves is that each of you work in one form or another in an area or a discipline where I think, like you just said, Andrea, where something incompressible enters the picture, that the human element
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: of randomness.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: I tend to think about this in terms of the way that sociophysics equations model mobs and marathons and other large collective human activities using turbulent fluid dynamics equations.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: You zoom out far enough,
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And decisions kind of disappear into this boil of probability.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And I remember, you know, in the first episode of Complexity Podcast, SFI's president, David Krakauer, said that science is about finding the efficient encodings of regular phenomena, but art...
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: is about expressing the incompressible.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And I'm curious where each of you, like Tim, your work is on trying to predict behavior that is at least conventionally thought of as profoundly unpredictable.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Meredith, you work as an artist.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And I also identify as an artist and worked
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: self-employed as an artist for over a decade.

text: And Michaela, in communication, there's something about not just being a megaphone, not just blasting one message to every possible listener, but knowing who you're speaking to.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And that requires a different way of thinking that's, in part,
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: it's like easy to, to fit that into complex systems thinking, because you're looking at, you know, context dependencies.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: But in another way, it's,
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: It is a form of art.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Science communication does require one to make some kind of incompressible Hail Mary passes as a communicator.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So I'm just curious where each of you sit with this tension between...
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: I mean, when we, you know, we say that randomness is the human, but it's also, you know, it's on display at any scale that we, that we look as long as we're core screening at, you know, at some, you know, it's, it, it seems almost more like a, uh, an artifact of the, the resolution at which we are able to explore a given phenomenon.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And I'm just, I'm curious how, how each of you, uh,
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: digest these ideas or, or, or use them in your work or that kind of thing.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And I'm not going to, I'm going to let whoever wants to speak up, speak up here.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: I can say something really quickly, which is I love this word incompressibility that you used, which it seems to me as if it might be like the way that I've been used to thinking about art, which is that it's about the questions that don't have answers.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: really that if we are going to divide things into categories of art and science and the things to which an answer might potentially be found would fall more on the science and art as about the questions like what is love, what is death, all kinds of things, but things that don't really have one answer.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And so I don't know if that's exactly what you mean by incompressibility, but I'll throw that out there.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Any other brave souls?
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Go ahead, Michaela.

text: It's interesting because what Meredith was saying is also valid in communication because you don't communicate without purpose or you never communicate without a purpose.

text: And when we don't communicate, we do communicate.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Not communicating is also a way of communicating.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so...
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: At every point in communication, you see the purpose of the person expressed.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And each person has its individuality, its culture, its past, its future, and its dreams.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so maybe communication is the art of trying to put people into links,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: to link people, to create new clusters of thought and to further that into common schools of thought and common communities and communities that bridge across communities.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we need art for that, the art of the imprevisible.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And I think that's also why we communicators really dream of bridging science and the wider public
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: different disciplines and sciences.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Of course, culture is very important for me, intercultural, interlinguistic communication.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And also, of course, with biomimicry, the link to nature, the reconnection to the whole.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So I can resonate with Meredith in that.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And just to touch back on this concept of randomness, I'll throw it out there that I don't think
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: there's actually as much randomness as we tend to think there is, as much as there might be this term we've talked about before, bounded chaos or the appearance of chaos and dealing with violence, which often like a term that aggravates me is when you hear something like random violence.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And studying this, very little violence is random.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: People take actions well in advance, which will lead them down the path to being violent.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: There are conditions that give rise to predispositions and effects.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And it seems random to us as a bystander.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And I think this gets into the question of the incomprehensibility of the system.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: and the importance of art and communication.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Because I think a lot of what, if you look back at before germ theory, disease looked random, perhaps.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Who was infected?
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: How were they infected?
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: What I see system science, complexity science, whatever you want to describe, is a way of diving into to make this seemingly random bounded chaos make sense in a structure
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: But then also recognize with humility, we can never really understand even with that structure, what's necessarily going to happen next.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And that's the part that I think ties it back to the appearance of randomness is that we can understand why things are happening, but there's so much going on.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And it's so varied.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: And then to explain that in a way that helps people understand, not just from education, but make informed policy choices and understand options is really goes from science back to art.

text: And I have nothing but respect for these memes I see on web pages that try and describe very complicated, complex systems concepts in a simple cartoon.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: and can do more in an image than I can do in a 10,000 word post.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: So I just see these connections coming together.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Andrea, did you have any thoughts on that?

text: Yes, yes, but I was helped by all of them because they prepared for something very special that I will try to convey as I hear Meredith and Michaela explaining the

text: This is the most important mark of a human being.

text: And when Tim comes concerned with violence and he gives me a gift, as soon as you started and Michael proposed the theme, I remembered a quote that my advisor on the PhD, he has sent me at some point of my research.

speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But I didn't know if he had a deeper relationship with what I was trying to defend.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Until the moment he has sent me a quote that I don't know.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I don't know the author, but it said, if the world was really random, there wouldn't be so much injustice.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Because injustice is regularity.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And I agree with Tim completely.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: strongly that everything we suffer from is regular.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Medicine was born from the exams by pathologists, post-mortem exams of bodies.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We know what we die of.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: That's regular.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We learn how we ache and burn.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But we are enchanted by what comes as random.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So I don't think we suffer from randomness.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And this is a kind of a changing perspective, because we're usually saying, no, I'm safe with what I know.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And I'm safe if the world remains as it is for me, and I have my perspective on things.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I can defend myself if things go this way or that way, because things are regular.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But I think it's exactly the opposite.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Human beings are more comfortable with randomness than with regularity.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Regularity is what traps us, what makes life repetitive, what will not allow us to listen to someone else.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: When we are deeply listening to someone, we are listening to random information.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: When every information that is added to a dialogue is random.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: If it's not random, it's not added.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So I'm completely with you, Tim, with this.

text: And I would love to learn more about your work because I think when you have an artist, you have a communicator, you have someone who is concerned about violence, we're all pro-randomness.

text: So what I would like to emphasize is just the difference between unpredictability and randomness as we're speaking about.

Brian Arthur at PARC, an SFI on economics and nouns and verbs, where he was saying it's time for the scientific study of economics to embrace the description of economic systems with algorithms
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Because there are things that usefully appear through that mode of inquiry that do not appear when you're using algebraic equations.

text: Because algebraic equations, he argues, describe the world as nouns, as static objects with perhaps dynamic relationships, but they're not adaptive relationships.
speaker: SPEAKER_05
